cells.data:
3 major questions for mobile robots:
  • Where am I?
  • where am i going
  • how do i get there? 

To answer these questions,
  • model the environment
    • given or built automatically
  • perceive and analyze env
  • plan and execute move



perception (sensing -> information extraction) —> localization Map building —> cognition path planning —> motion control module
  • perception is noisy 
  • incorrect data can affect thinking
  • motors have errors

Perception and thinking happen at different rates
  • 60 Hz for image, 100 Hz for motors and much slower for thinking/path planning


Motion control is forward kinematics and inverse kinematics.
Inverse kinematics is harder.

Perception
  • IMU: inertial measuring unit
    • orientation of the vehicle.
    • Error accumulates though
  • GPU:
    • not good precision, and would lose signal sometimes.

Markov localization
See - generate a probability distribution of locations in a priori map based on what you can see
act - move 1 meter, and generate another distribution for where the robot could be right now
see - see again, and generate another distribution.
Add the distributions together, and you should see a peak.


Global path planning
  • getting somewhere without collision
local path planning
  • go without collision

raw data —> features —> objects —> places/situations
  • raw data -> features is done with models
  • features —> objects is semantics
  • objects —> places/situations is relationships + context
You have to take temporal changes into consideration

3D SLAM



Biped walking, another locomotive way of transform
  • rolling polygon with side length equal to stride



gait is distinct sequence of lift and releaese events of individual legs.
Human legs have 6 gaits


sttatically stable
COG must be in polygon of all other grounded legs.

dynamically stable
COG must be on line of two of the legs
